title: How to Repair a Fiberglass Tub or Shower

steps.headline: Confirm that your tub or shower is fiberglass before planning the repair.
steps.description: If you’re not sure if your tub or shower is fiberglass, tap on it with your knuckle or a wooden spoon. It should make a soft, hollow, non-metallic sound, and may even flex a bit. A cast iron or steel tub or shower pan will make a metallic, deeper, more solid “clanging” sound. Repairing damage to metal tubs and showers is best left to a professional.

steps.headline: Check the size and location of the damage to determine if you can fix it.
steps.description: If there’s a small crack or hole due to dropping something or accidentally kicking the tub wall, a fiberglass tub repair kit should work well. However, if the crack is more than about 0.5 in (1.3 cm) wide or the hole is more than about 1 in (2.5 cm) in diameter, consider hiring a professional. A crack that wasn't caused by external damage (like dropping the shampoo bottle) is probably due to poor structural support below the fiberglass. It may be possible to repair this by drilling holes in the fiberglass and injecting a 2-component, low-density foam, but it's usually best to hire a pro. If there’s a hole larger than 1 in (2.5 cm) in the flat bottom of your fiberglass shower pan, it’s possible to repair it by removing the pan, adhering a plywood patch to the underside with epoxy, reinstalling the shower pan, and fixing the hole with a repair kit. Unless you’re experienced with this type of work, though, hire a pro instead.

steps.headline: Pick a suitable fiberglass tub repair kit at your local home center.
steps.description: There are several brands to choose from, but they all work in essentially the same fashion. Ask a store employee or friends who have made tub repairs for advice on the best brand choice for your needs. Most kits come with colorants (tinting products) to change the color of the product to match common fiberglass tub or shower colors, such as white, off-white, and almond. Most kits come with everything you’ll need, but you may have to purchase some items separately in some cases. Check the kit packaging for the following items: polyester resin, a hardener catalyst, a fiberglass mesh or mat, colorants, sandpaper in assorted grits, resin thickener, protective gloves, a mixing container, and a stirring tool.

steps.headline: Put on personal protective gear for use throughout the repair.
steps.description: Use the protective gloves that come with the kit, or get sturdy disposable cleaning gloves. Wear safety glasses to make sure no chemicals or fiberglass particles get into your eyes. Additionally, wear a dust mask or, even better, a respirator to protect your airways. Keep the bathroom well ventilated while working. For example, open a window and turn on the bathroom exhaust fan.

steps.headline: Clean the area around the damage before starting your repair.
steps.description: Use a sponge dipped in a household cleaner like rubbing alcohol or acetone to wipe away any wax, oil, or soap scum. Give the cleaner 1-2 minutes to dry before proceeding. The repair resin may not adhere properly if you skip this simple step.

steps.headline: Sand the damaged area lightly, then clean it once again.
steps.description: If you’re dealing with a hole or a small crack, lightly sand the damaged area and about 1 in (2.5 cm) all around it with 80-grit sandpaper, just enough to make the surface a bit rough. Then, wipe away any sanding debris with your cleaning sponge and chosen household cleaner. If you have a crack that’s at least 0.125 in (0.32 cm) wide, consider using a rotary tool with an 80-grit sandpaper attachment to create a bevel on either side of the crack. In other words, use the rotary tool to create a narrow, shallow “canyon” with the crack representing the winding “river” at the bottom. Do this between cleanings. You can skip using the rotary tool on larger cracks if you’re not comfortable working with one, but beveling the crack will help the resin fill in the damaged area.

steps.headline: Cut a sheet of fiberglass reinforcing cloth to fit the damage, if needed.
steps.description: You’ll need to use the reinforcing cloth if you’re dealing with a hole of any size, or if it’s a crack over 0.25 in (0.64 cm) wide. Use the sheet that comes with your repair kit, and cut it so that it’s at least 1 in (2.5 cm) larger on all sides than the hole or crack. You can cut the reinforcing cloth with standard household scissors. Don’t worry about matching the shape of the damaged area perfectly. The important thing is to make sure the cloth is larger than the damaged area on all sides.

steps.headline: Set up the kit and familiarize yourself with its mixing instructions.
steps.description: Once mixed, the resin materials in these kits are meant to harden very quickly—sometimes as fast as 5 minutes. Different kit brands have different instructions, so read everything carefully so there are no delays or mistakes once you start combining the resin. If your kit does not come with its own mixing tray or board, grab a scrap of sturdy cardboard that’s about the size of a standard sheet of paper. Put on your personal protective gear before opening any of the containers or tubes in the kit. Keep the gear on throughout the process of mixing up and applying the patch material.

steps.headline: Dispense the amount of resin you need, based on the product instructions.
steps.description: Your selected kit may, for example, instruct you to dispense a quarter (¼) of the resin material for a small crack or hole, half (½) for a medium crack or hole, or all of the resin for a large crack or hole. Always over-estimate rather than under-estimate so you don’t need to mix up more resin in the middle of your repair job. Dispense the resin into the mixing container, if provided. If your kit doesn’t come with a mixing container, dispense the resin onto your scrap of cardboard. You’ll be able to mix it up there. The resin material often has the look and consistency of white toothpaste.

steps.headline: Add colorant, if needed, from the provided tube in the kit.
steps.description: If you have a standard white fiberglass tub or shower, you likely won’t need to add any colorant (check the kit instructions). If you do need to add coloring—for instance, to get an almond shade—add the colorant precisely according to the instructions and stir it in thoroughly with the provided stirring stick. For instance, if you’re using half of the provided amount of resin, the kit may instruct you to use 5 drops of the “almond” colorant to get that finish color. Do your best to dispense precisely 5 drops from the colorant tube. You don’t have to rush while stirring in the colorant, because the resin won’t start to harden until you mix in the hardener.

steps.headline: Mix in the thickening agent, if applicable, for vertical repairs.
steps.description: If you’re making a repair to a vertical surface, such as the side wall of the tub, some repair kits provide a separate thickening agent to stir into the resin. This will help prevent the mixed resin from running out of the hole or crack before it hardens. If your kit has a thickener and you’re fixing a vertical surface, mix it in as directed. Not all kits come with thickeners. Don’t worry about trying to add a thickener if your kit doesn’t provide one, even if you’re fixing a vertical fiberglass surface.

steps.headline: Stir in the hardener according to the kit’s instructions.
steps.description: The hardener is typically a thick liquid or thin gel found in a separate, labeled tube. Add the precise amount directed by the kit, based on the amount of resin you’re using. If you use too little, the patch may not harden correctly. If you use too much, it may harden before you’re able to apply it to the tub or shower. For example, if you’re using one-fourth of the provided resin, you might be instructed to add 5 drops of hardener. Do your best to add exactly 5 drops in this case. Stir the mixture with your stirring stick until the hardener is incorporated, but don’t spend excessive time stirring. You’re now “on the clock” for the material to start hardening!

steps.headline: Fill a smaller crack or hole completely with the patch material.
steps.description: For a smaller repair that doesn’t require the use of a mesh patch, scoop up about half of the mixed patch material with a stirring stick, tongue depressor, or small putty knife. Press the material firmly into the crack, then scoop up more material and mound it over the top of the crack so that it’s a bit above the level of the surrounding fiberglass. If you don’t mound up the patch material now, it will shrink while hardening and end up below the level of the current fiberglass. In this case, you’ll have to mix up and add more patch material. Remember to work with a purpose—you may have only 5-10 minutes before the mixture starts to harden!

steps.headline: Surround a larger hole or crack with patch material before adding the mesh.
steps.description: If you’re using a mesh patch to repair a larger crack or hole, scoop up just enough repair material at this time to create a base layer around the damaged spot. Make sure you add enough to that you can nestle and adhere the mesh patch in place over the damage. Mound the remainder of the mixed patch material over the mesh patch once you put it in place.

steps.headline: Stick the mesh, if needed, over the repair spot and cover it with patch material.
steps.description: With your gloved fingers, gently press the cut piece of fiberglass mesh over the crack or hole. It should stick in place due to the base layer of patch material you put down. Then, scoop up more of the patch material and smooth it over and about  0.5 in (1.3 cm) beyond the edges of the mesh patch until the mesh is no longer visible. Remember to mound up the patch material a little above the surface of the tub or shower. It will shrink somewhat while hardening, and you’ll be sanding down the hardened patch material anyway.

steps.headline: Sand the hardened patch carefully, after the instructed curing time.
steps.description: The patch material will likely harden in 10-15 minutes, but the package may instruct you to let it cure for a longer period—for instance, 2 hours—before sanding it. After this curing time, use the coarsest sandpaper that came with the kit to begin sanding down the patch material. Use light, even strokes, and be careful not to scratch the surrounding fiberglass. As the patch material approaches being level with the surrounding fiberglass, switch to sequentially finer grits of sandpaper—your kit may come with 3-4 different sheets, for example. Use a lighter touch and be more careful as the sandpaper becomes finer, so that you end up with a smooth, even patch job that feels level with the surrounding fiberglass. If your kit doesn’t come with sandpaper, start with 80-grit and work your way up to 240-grit or higher.

steps.headline: Use finishing polish or buffing compound to add a glossy finish.
steps.description: Follow your kit’s instructions for specific application procedures. You might, for instance, add a bit of the finishing polish to a clean rag and buff it into the hardened patch material. When you’re done, the patch area should have the same glossy appearance as the surrounding fiberglass. No matter how great of a job you do, you’ll likely be able to see the patched area if you look closely enough. However, from a distance, it should blend in and be virtually impossible to spot. Regardless, it’s better than having an obvious crack or hole in your tub or shower!

No matter how great of a job you do, you’ll likely be able to see the patched area if you look closely enough.
However, from a distance, it should blend in and be virtually impossible to spot.
Regardless, it’s better than having an obvious crack or hole in your tub or shower!
